captions.text:
I'm going to talk you through how to properly
do a squat. There's a million different ways

of doing a squat. I'm just going to show you
the basic body weight squat, meaning you don't

have any weight that you're working with except
yourself. As you get stronger, you might want

to progress - holding a medicine ball, holding
a weight, or even holding your kid, anything

that's going to add weight to your legs. This
is predominantly a lower based exercise so

you're going to focus on your quadriceps muscle
groups, your gluts, your hamstrings, and your

whole posterior chain. Basically, all of the
muscles of the lower body are going to be
working in this exercise.

You want to start with your feet probably
about shoulder width apart. If you're more

comfortable a little wider or even externally
rotating your fit a bit, just find place that's

comfortable for your hips and make sure that
your knees always track. A good rule of thumb

is to think about your knees going right in
between your big toe and your second toe.

When you're doing a squat just watch out that
your knees are not adducting and collapsing

in or abducting and going out. You want to
try to maintain the knee in a neutral position

The wider you are too, the easier it's going
be to balance. If you have stability issues,

start wide. If you want to challenge the stability,
then you bring your legs a little closer together

and challenge your core muscles by challenging
your balance.

So, standard squat, shoulder width. Something
comfortable. You're going to imagine like

you're sitting back into a chair, lengthening
your spine, reaching your hips back, bending

your knees, and then exhale to come up. You're
always going to inhale as you lower your body

and you're always going to exhale as you lift
any weight. In this case, the weight is your

body. Exhale, pull the abs in, and come up
to vertical tall spine.

My tips for the squat, again, aside from the
knees is what's going on with your spine.

I'm going to show you from the side. If you're
facing side you could look at yourself in

a mirror and watch your positioning if that
helps you when you're first learning. Same

thing, sitting back like you're sitting back
into a chair and watching that your spine

is neutral. That means I'm not doing hyper
extension, and I'm not doing excessive flection.

I'm just trying to be right in between. You
have natural curves to your spine, so you

want to maintain those, so nothing excessive
forwards or backwards of that. Then just do

as many reps as you can do, maintaining good
form, breathing in on the way down, exhale

on the way up, targeting all the major muscle
groups of the lower body.

title: How to Do a Squat | Boot Camp Workout

comments.author: Fay Nix

comments.text:
The squat she teaches does not engage the posterior chain as she claims. 
For those that aren't aware, the posterior chain consists of you 
Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Glutes and Adductors (thigh muscles). The video 
shows a quad dominant squat which because of parallel toe position excludes 
the majority of the posterior chain.

I guarantee anyone trying this squat feels it on the front of the legs and 
little to none on their hamstrings, inner thighs or Glutes. 

Now try the squat with a shoulder width stance and feet turned out roughly 
30 degrees and sit down into your heels keeping lower back straight and 
knees following in the path as the toes. When at the bottom drive your hips 
up by pushing into your heels and now see where you feel it!

This engages hip drive which in turn calls upon the posterior chain to lift 
you up and because your thighs are opened slightly the thigh muscles are 
recruited as part of the posterior chain.

In closing I appreciate this is a beginners demonstration but I believe 
calling out discrepancies such as I have more relevant because it's a 
beginners video. 

If flexibility is an issue then that should addressed before attempting a 
squat of any nature. If you simply want to target the quads for some 
bizarre reason the use a leg extension machine and leave squats out.
﻿

comments.text:
You could also work on your flexibility and try to get lower.  The lower 
you go, the more you will be using your glutes and hamstring to come back 
up.  I would also incorporate more deadlifts into your workout.  Those are 
a much more "butt-isolating" exercise than squats are and don't develop the 
thighs.  WIth stiff-legged deadlifts, you are focusing solely on those 
glutes, and also strenghtening your back as well.
comments.author: Heidi Speaker

comments.text:
I'd say that's completely ok, just try to increase the amount of squats by 
having a plan. Like: Monday: 15-20 squats II Tuesday: Rest II Wednesday: 20 
squats II Thursday: Rest II Friday: 20 -25 squats and so on. Just test your 
limits and adjust your plan, and it will get easier over time (this also 
counts for your balance as you get used to the exercise). Also, be sure to 
rewatch this video and check your form from time to time. :)

comments.author: skateNappreciate

comments.text:
You're either doing it wrong or have very weak knees. No matter what, DO 
NOT exercise if your knees hurt! Give them a day or two (or however long it 
takes) of rest, and when all the pain is gone attempt the correct 
technique. My guess would be that you tried to keep your back upright 
(instead of almost parallel to the ground. Your knee should never, ever 
extend further than your toes! (and that's what happens when you don't keep 
your back almost parallel to the ground) That puts huge strain on your 
joints. So:

- feet flat on the ground
- more or less shoulder wide
- toes pointing straight or slightly outside (depending on the build of 
your hips)
- straight back bending forward
- knees 'track' the toes (no going outside or inside)
- knees never, ever go further forward than the toes
- weight is on your heels, not toes
- your but should be sticking out pretty far back (and not be over your 
ankles)

If this doesn't help your knees are really fucked up.

comments.author: energeez

comments.text:
Hey Charlette, it could be all of the above that everyone has said. your 
squat is focusing on your butt. So lean back like you're sitting in a 
chair. If you're still in pain do some quad or kempo quad stretches. Maybe 
some hamstring work. If still no results I would suggest strengthening you 
legs before squatting.  No need to rush and get hurt. If you have any 
questions feel free to message me or find me on facebook :)
